titleStmt.title: A Most pleasaunt and excellent conceited Co-medie, of Syr Iohn Falstaffe, and the merrie Wiues of Windsor. Entermixed with sundrie variable and pleasing humors, of Syr Hugh the Welch Knight, Iustice Shallow, and his wise Cousin M. Slender. With the swaggering vaine of Auncient Pistoll, and Corporall Nym. By William Shakespeare. As it hath bene diuers times Acted by the right Honorable my Lord Chamberlaines seruants. Both before her Maiestrie, and else-where.

respStmt.name: Tanmay Shah
respStmt.resp: regularised, homographs tagged, and spelling modernised by
respStmt.name: Hugh Craig

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by T.C. for Arthur Iohnson, and are to be sold at his shop in Powles Church-yard, at the signe of the Flower de Leuse and the Crowne.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Robert Shallow, country Justice Sir Hugh Evans, a Welsh parson Slender, cousin to Shallow Page, a gentleman dwelling at Windsor Falstaff, Sir John Falstaff Pistol Bardolfe, sharper attending on Falstaff Nym, sharper attending on Falstaff Mistress Ford Mistress Page Anne Page, Mistress Page's daughter Simple, servant to Slender Host, host of the Garter Inn Mistress Quickly, hostess of a tavern in Eastcheap Doctor Caius, a French physician Rugby, servant to Doctor Caius Ford, a gentleman dwelling at Windsor Servant Fenton, a gentleman

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.head: A pleasant conceited Co-medie, of Syr Iohn Falstaffe, and the merry Wiues of Windsor.

div2.stage: Enter Iustice Shallow, Syr Hugh, Maister Page,and Slender.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Never talk to me, I will make a star-chamber matter of it.
The Council shall know it.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Nay good master Shallow be persuaded by me

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Nay, surely my uncle shall not put it upso.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Will you not hear reasons Master. Slenders?
You should hear reasons.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Though he be a knight, he shall not think to
carry it so away.
Master. Page I will not be wronged. For you
Sir, I love you, and for my cousin
He comes to look upon your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And here is my hand, and if my daughter
Like him so well as I, we will quickly have it a match:
In the mean time let me entreat you to sojourn
Here a while. And on my life I will undertake
To make you friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I pray you Master. Shallowes let it be so.
The matter is pud to arbitrarments.
The first man is Master. Page, videlicet Master. Page.
The second is myself, videlicet myself.
And the third and last man, is mine host of the garter.

div2.stage: Enter Syr Iohn Falstaffe, Pistoll, Bardolfe,and Nim

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Here is sir Iohn himself now, look you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Now Master. Shallow, you will complain of me
to the Council, I hear?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, sir Iohn, you have hurt my keeper,
Killed my dogs, stolen my deer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: But not kissed your keepers daughter.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well this shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I will answer it strait
This is now answered

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well, the Council shall know it

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It were better for you it were known in counsel,
You will be laughed at

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Good words sir Iohn, good words

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Good words, good Cabbage
Slender I brake your head,
What matter have you against me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I have matter in my head against you and
your cogging companions, Pistoll and Nym
carried me to the Tavern and made me drunk,
and afterward picked my pocket

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What say you to this Pistoll, did you pick
Master Slenders purse Pistoll?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye by this handkercher did he. Two fair
shovel board shillings, besides seven groats in mill
sixpences

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What say you to this Pistoll?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, and Master mine, I combat crave
Of this same latin bilbo
Even in thy gorge, thy gorge, thy gorge

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: By this light it was he then

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Sir my honour is not for many words,
But if you run base humours of me,
I will say marry trap

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You hear these matters denied gentlemen,
You hear it

div2.stage: Enter Mistresse Foord, Mistresse Page, and her daughter Anne.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No more now,
I think it be almost dinner time,
For my wife is come to meet us

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mistress Foord, I think your name is,
If I mistake not

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford
sp.l: Your mistake sir is nothing but in the
Mistress. But my husband's name is Foord sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I shall desire your more acquaintance
The like of you good mistress Page

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: With all my heart sir Iohn
Come husband will you go?
Dinner stays for us

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: With all my heart, come along Gentlemen

div2.stage: Exit all, but Slender and mistresse Anne.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Now forsooth why do you stay me?
What would you with me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Nay for my own part, I would little or nothing
with you. I love you well, and my uncle can
tell you how my living stands. And if you can love
me why so. If not, why then happy man be his dole

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You say well Master. Slender
But first you must give me leave to
Be acquainted with your humour,
And afterward to love you if I can

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Why by God, there is never a man in christendom
can desire more. What have you Bears
in your Town mistress Anne, your dogs bark so?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I cannot tell Master

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Ha how say you? I warrant you are afeared of
a Bear let loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Yes trust me

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Now that is meat and drink to me,
I will run yon to a Bear, and take her by the mussell,
You never saw the like
But indeed I cannot blame you,
For they are marvelous rough things

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Will you go in to dinner Master. Slendor?
The meat stays for you

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: No faith not I. I thank you,
I cannot abide the smell of hot meat
Never since I broke my shin. I will tell you how it came
By my troth. A Fencer and I played three venies
For a dish of stewed prunes, and I with my ward
Defending my head, he hot my shin. Yes faith

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Come, come Master Slender, dinner stays for you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I can eat no meat, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You shall not choose I say.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I will follow you sir, pray lead the way.
Nay be God mistress Anne, you shall go first,
I have more manners than so, I hope.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Well sir, I will not be troublesome.

div2.stage: Enter sir Hugh and Simple, from dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.p:
Hark you Simple, pray you bear this letter
to Doctor Cayus house, the French Doctor. He is
dwell up along the street, and enquire of his house
for one mistress Quickly, his woman, or his try nurse,
and deliver this Letter to her, it it is about Master
Slender. Look you, will you do it now?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Pray you do, I must not be absent at the
grace.
I will go make an end of my dinner,
There is pepions and cheese behind.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn Falstaffes Host of the Garter, Nym, Bardolfe, Pistoll, and the boy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What says my bully Rooke?
Speak scholarly and wisely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mine Host, I must turn away some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Discard bully, Hercules cashier.
Let them wag, trot, trot.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I sit at ten pound a week.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Thou art an Emperor Cæsar, Phesser and
Kesar bully.
I will entertain Bardolfe. He shall tap, he shall draw.
Said I well, bully Hector?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Do good mine Host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I have spoke. Let him follow. Bardolfe
Let me see thee froth, and lime. I am at
A word. Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Do Bardolfe, a Tapster is a good trade,
An old cloak will make a new Jerkin,
A withered serving-man, a fresh Tapster:
Follow him Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
I will sir, I will warrant you I will make a good
shift to live.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: O base gongarian wight, wilt thou the spicket willed?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
His mind is not heroic. And there is the
humour of it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well my Lads, I am almost out at the
heels.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Why then let kibes ensue. Nym. I thank thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well I am glad I am so rid of this tinder
Boy.
His stealth was too open, his filching was like
An unskilful singer, he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: The good humour is to steal at a minute's
rest.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: It is so indeed Nym, thou hast hit it right.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, afore God, I must cheat, I must cony-catch.
Which of you knows Foord of this Town?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I ken the wight, he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well my honest Lads, I will tell you what
I am about.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Two yards and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No gibes now Pistoll: indeed I am two yards
In the waist, but now I am about no waste:
Briefly, I am about thrift you rogues you,
I do intend to make love to Foords wife,
I espy entertainment in her. She carves, she
Discourses. She gives the lyre of invitation,
And every part to be construed rightly is, I am
Sir Iohn Falstaffes.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: He hath studied her well, out of honesty
Into English.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Now the report goes, she hath all the rule
Of her husbands purse. She hath legions of angels.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: As many devils attend her.
And to her boy say I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Here is a Letter to her. Here is another to
mistress Page.
Who even now gave me good eyes too, examined
my exteriors with such a greedy intention, with the
beams of her beauty, that it seemed as she would
have scourged me up like a burning glass. Here is another Letter to her, she bears the purse too. They
shall be Exchequers to me, and I will be cheaters to
them both. They shall be my East and West Indies
and I will trade to them both. Here bear thou this
Letter to mistress Foord. And thou this to mistress Page.
We will thrive Lads, we will thrive.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Shall I sir Panderowes of Troy become?
And by my sword were steel.
Then Lucifer take all.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Here take your humour Letter again,
For my part, I will keep the behaviour
Of reputation. And there is the humour of it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Here sirrah bear me these Letters titely,
Sail like my pinnace to the golden shores:
Hence slaves, avaunt. Vanish like hailstones, go.
Falstaffe will learn the humour of this age,
French thrift you rogue, myself and skirted Page.
and the Boy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: And art thou gone? Teaster I will have in pouch
When thou shalt want, base Phrygian Turke.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
I have operations in my head, which are
humours of revenge.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Wilt thou revenge?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: By Welkin and her Fairies.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: By wit, or sword?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
With both the humours I will disclose this
love to Page. I will poses him with Iallowes,
And there is the humour of it.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: And I to Foord will likewise tell
How Falstaffe varlet vild,
Would have her love, his dove would prove,
And eke his bed defile.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Let us about it then.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I will second thee : sir Corporal Nym troop on.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Master. Slender is your Masters name say you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye indeed that is his name.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: How say you? I take it he is somewhat a
weakly man:
And he has as it were a whey coloured beard.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Indeed my master's beard is cane coloured.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Cane colour, you say well.
And is this Letter from sir Yon, about Mistress Anne,
Is it not?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye indeed is it.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p:
So: and your Master would have me as
it it were to speak to mistress Anne concerning him:
I promise you my Master.
hath a great affectioned mind
to mistress Anne himself. And if he should know
that I should as they say, give my verdict for any one
but himself, I should hear of it thoroughly : For
I tell you friend, he puts all his privities in me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye by my faith you are a good stay to hiM.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Am I? Aye if you knew all you would say so:
Washing, brewing, baking, all goes through my hands,
Or else it would be but a woe house.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye beshrew me, one woman to do all this,
Is very painful.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Are you advised of that? Aye, I warrant you,
Take all, and pay all, all go through my hands,
And he is such a honest man, and he should chance
To come home and find a man here, we should
Have no who with him. He is a parlous man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Is he indeed?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Is he quoth you? God keep him abroad:
Lord bless me, who knocks there?
For Gods sake step into the Counting-house,
While I go see who is at door.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn,
Are you come home sir already?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Aye begar I be forget my ointment,
Where be Iohn Rugby?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Here sir, do you call?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Aye you be Iohn Rugbie, and you be Iack Rugby
Go run up met your heels, and bring away
The ointment in the window present:
Make haste Iohn Rugbie. O I am almost forget
My simples in a box in the Counting-house:
O Ieshu what be here, a devil, a devil?
My Rapier Iohn Rugby, What be you, what make
You in my Counting-house?
I think you be a thief.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Ieshu bless me, we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O Lord sir no: I am no thief.
I am a Serving-man :
My name is Iohn Simple, I brought a Letter sir
From my Master. Slender, about mistress Anne Page.
Sir : Indeed that is my coming.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Aye begar is that all? Iohn Rugby give a ma pen
An Ink:tarche vn pettit tarche a little.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O God what a furious man is this?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Nay it is well he is no worse:
I am glad he is so quiet.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Here give that same to sir Hu, it ber ve challenge
Begar tell him I will cut his nose, will you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye sir, I will tell him so.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: That be well , my Rapier Iohn Rugby, follow may,

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Well my friend, I cannot tarry, tell your
Master I will do what I can for him,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Marry will I, I am glad I am got hence.

div2.stage: Enter Mistresse Page, reading of a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: Mistress Page I love you. Ask me no reason,
Because they are impossible to allege. You are fair,
And I am fat. You love sack, so do I:
As I am sure I have no mind but to love,
So I know you have no heart but to grant
A soldier doth not use many words, where he knows
A letter may serve for a sentence. I love you,
And so I leave you.
Yours Sir Iohn Falstaffe.
Now Ieshu bless me, am I metamorphosed?
I think I know not myself. Why what a-god's
name doth this man see in me, that thus he shoots
at my honesty? Well but that I know my own
heart, I should scarcely persuade myself I were
hand. Why what an unreasonable woolsack is this.
He was never twice in my company, and if then I
thought I gave such assurance with my eyes, I would pull
them out, they should never see more holy days.
Well, I shall trust fat men the worse while I live for
his sake. O God that I knew how to be revenged of
him. But in good time, here is mistress Foord.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: How now Mistress Page, are you reading
Love Letters? How do you woman?

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: O woman I am I know not what:
In love up to the hard ears. I was never in such a
case in my life.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: In love, now in the name of God with
whom?

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: With one that swears he loves me,
And I must not choose but do the like again:
I prithee look on that Letter.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: I will match your letter just with the like,
Line for line, word for word. Only the name
Of mistress Page, and mistress Foord disagrees:
Do me the kindness to look upon this.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: Why this is right my letter.
O most notorious villain!
Why what a bladder of iniquity is this?
Let us be revenged whatsoever we do.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: Revenged, if we live we will be revenged.
O Lord if my husband should see this Letter,
Ifaith this would even give edge to his Jealousy.

div2.stage: Enter Ford, Page, Pistoll and Nym.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: See where our husbands are,
Mine is as far from Jealousy,
As I am from wronging him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Ford the words I speak are forced:
Beware, take heed, for Falstaffe loves thy wife:
When Pistoll lies do this.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Why sir my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: He woos both young and old, both rich and poor
None comes amiss.I say he loves thy wife:
Fair warning did I give, take heed,
For summer comes, and Cuckoo birds appear:
Page believe him what he says. Away sir Corporal Nym.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Sir the humour of it is, he loves your wife,
I should have borne the humour Letter to her:
I speak and I avouch it is true: My name is Nym.
Farewell, I love not the humour of bread and cheese:
And there is the humour of it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The humour of it, quoth you:
Here is a fellow frights humour out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: How now sweetheart, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How now man? How do you mistress Ford?

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: Well I thank you good Master. Page.
How now husband, how chance thou art so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Melancholy, I am not melancholy.
Go get you in, go.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: God save me, see who yonder is:
We will set her a-work in this business.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: O she will serve excellent.
Now you come to see my daughter Anne I am sure.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Aye forsooth that is my coming.

sp.speaker: Mis.Pa.
sp.l: Come go in with me. Come Mistress. Ford.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: I follow you Mistress Page.

div2.stage: Exit Mistresse Ford, Mis. Page, and Quickly.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Master. Page did you hear what these fellows said?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Yes Master. Ford, what of that sir?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Do you think it is true that they told us?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No by my troth do I not,
I rather take them to be paltry lying knaues,
Such as rather speaks of envy,
Than of any certain they have
Of anything . And for the knight, perhaps
He hath spoke merrily, as the fashion of fat men
Are: But should he love my wife,
Aye faith I owuld turn her loose to him:
And what he got more of her,
Than ill looks, and shrewd words,
Why let me bear the penalty of it.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Nay I do not mistrust my wife,
Yet I would be loath to turn them together,
A man may be too confident.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Here comes my ramping host of the garter,
There is either liquor in his head, or money in his purse,
That he looks so merrily. Now mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: God bless you my bully rookes, God bless you.
Cauelera Justice I say.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: At hand mine host, at hand. Master. Ford god den to you.
God den an twenty good Master. Page.
I tell you sir we have sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Tell him cauelira Justice: tell him bully rooke.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Mine Host of the garter:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What says my bully rooke?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: A word with you sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Hark you sir, I will tell you what the sport shall be,
Doctor Cayus and sir Hu are to fight,
My merry Host hath had the measuring
Of their weapons, and hath
Appointed them contrary places. Hark in your ear:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Hast thou no suit against my knight,
My guest, my cauellira:

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: None I protest: But tell him my name
Is Rrooke, only for a Jest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My hand bully: Thou shalt
Have egress and regress, and thy
Name shall be Brooke: Said I well bully Hector?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I tell you what Master. Page, I believe
The Doctor is no Jester, he will lay it on:
For though we be Justices and Doctors,
And Church men, yet we are
The sons of women Master. Page:

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: True master Shallow:

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: It will be found so master Page:

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Master Shallow you yourself
Have been a great fighter,
Though now a man of peace:

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Master. Page I have seen the day that young
Tall fellows with their stroke and their passado,
I have made them trudge Master Page,
Ah it is the heart, the heart doth all: I
Have seen the day, with my two hand sword
I would have made you four tall Fencers
Skipped like Rats.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Here boys, shall we wag, shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Ha with you mine host.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Come Master. Ford, shall we to dinner?
I know these fellows sticks in your mind.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: No in good sadness not in mine:
Yet for all this I will try it further,
I will not leave it so:
Come Master. Page, shall we to dinner?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: With all my heart sir, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I will retort the sum in equipage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not a penny: I have been content you
should lay my countenance to pawn: I have grated
upon my good friends for 3. reprieves, for you and
your Coach fellow Nym, else you might have looked
thorough a grate like a geminy of baboons. I am damned in hell for swearing to Gentlemen you are good
soldiers and tall fellows: And when mistress Briget lost the handle of her Fan, I took it on my honour thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Didst thou not share? hadst thou not fifteen pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Reason you rogue, reason.
Doest thou think I will endanger my soul gratis?
In brief, hang no more about me, I am no gibbet
for you. A short knife and a throng to your manner
of picked hatch, go. You will not bear a Letter for me
you rogue you: you stand upon your honour. Why
thou unconfinable baseness thou, it is as much as I
can do to keep the terms of my honour precise. I, I
myself sometimes, leaving the fear of God on
the left hand, am fain to shuffle, to filch and to lurch.
And yet you stand upon your honour, you rogue.
You, you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I do recant: what owuldst thou more of man?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, go to, away, no more.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Good you god den sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Good den fair wife.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Not so if it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Fair maid then.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: That I am I will be sworn, as my mother was
The first hour I was borne.
Sir I would speak with you in private.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Say on I prithee, here is none but my own
household.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Are they so? Now God bless them, and
make them his servants.
Sir I come from Mistress Foord.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: So from Mistress Foord. Go on.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Aye sir, she hath sent me to you to let you
Understand she hath received your Letter,
And let me tell you, she is one stands upon her credit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, come Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Aye sir, and as they say, she is not the first
Hath been led in a fool's paradise.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Nay prithee be brief my good she Mercury.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Marry sir, she would have you meet her between
eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: So between eight and nine:

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Aye forsooth, for then her husband goes a-birding,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well commend me to thy mistress, tell her
I will not fail her: Boy give her my purse.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Nay sir I have another errand to do to you
From mistress Page:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: From mistress Page? I prithee what of her?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: By my troth I think you work by Enchantments,
Else they could never love you as they do:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Not I, I assure thee: setting the attraction of my
Good parts aside, I use no other enchantments:

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Well sir, she loves you extremely:
And let me tell you, she is one that fears God,
And her husband gives her leave to do all:
For he is not half so jealousy as Master. Ford is.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: But hark thee, hath mistress Page and mistress Ford,
Acquainted each other how dearly they love me?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: O God no sir: there were a jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well farewell, commend me to mistress Ford,
I will not fail her say.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: God be with your worship

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sir here is a Gentleman,
One Master. Brooke, would speak with you,
He hath sent you a cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Master. Brooke, he is welcome: Bid him come up,
Such Brookes are always welcome to me:
A Iack, will thy old body yet hold out?
Wilt thou after the expense of so much money
Be now a gainer? Good body I thank thee,
And I will make more of thee than I have done:
Ha, ha, mistress Ford, and mistress Page, have
I caught you on the hip? go to.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And you too, would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Marry would I sir, I am somewhat bold to trouble you,
My name is Brooke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Good Master. Brooke you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Ifaith sir I am a gentleman and a traveller,
That have seen somewhat. And I have often heard
That if money goes before, all ways lie open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Money is a good soldier sir, and will on.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Ifaith sir, and I have a bag here,
Would you would help me to bear it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O Lord, would I could tell how to deserve
To be your porter.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: That may you easily sir Iohn: I have an earnest
Suit to you. But good sir Iohn when I have
Told you my grief, cast one eye of your own
Estate, since yourself knew what it is to be
Such an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Very well sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Sir I am deeply in love with one Fords wife
Of this Town. Now sir Iohn you are a gentleman
Of good discoursing, well beloved among Ladies,
A man of such parts that might win 20. such as she.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O good sir.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Nay believe it sir Iohn, for it is time. Now my love
Is so grounded upon her, that without her love
I shall hardly live.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Have you importuned her by any means?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: No never Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Of what quality is your love then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Ifaith sir, like a fair house set upon
Another man's foundation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And to what end have you unfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: O sir, when I have told you that, I told you all:
For she sir stands so pure in the firm state
Of her honesty, that she is too bright to be looked
Against: Now could I come against her
With some detection, I should sooner persuade her
From her marriage vow, and a hundred such nice
Terms that she will stand upon.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why would it apply well to the fervency
of your affection,
That another should possess what you would enjoy?
Methinks you prescribe very preposterously
To yourself.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: No sir, for by that means should I be certain of that which I now misdoubt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well Master. Brooke, I will first make bold with your money,
Next, give me your hand. Lastly, you shall
And you will, enjoy Fords wife.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: O good sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Master. Brooke, I say you shall.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Want no money Sir Iohn, you shall want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Want no Mistress Ford Master. Brooke,
You shall want none. Even as you came to me,
Her spokesmate, her go-between parted from me:
I may tell you Master. Brooke, I am to meet her
Between 8. and 9. for at that time the Jealous
Cuckally knave her husband will be from home,
Come to me soon at night, you shall know how
I speed Master. Brooke.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Sir do you know Ford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hang him poor cuckally knave, I know him not,
And yet I wrong him to call him poor. For they
Say the cuckally knave hath legions of angels,
For the which7H61; his wife seems to me well favoured,
And I will use her as the key of the cuckally knaues
Coffer, and there is my rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Methinks sir it were very good that you knew
Ford, that you might shun hiM.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hang him cuckally knave, I will stare him
Out of his wits, I will keep him in awe
With this my cudgel: It shall hang like a meteor
Over the wittolly knaues head, Master. Brooke thou shalt
See I will predominate over the peasant,
And thou shalt lie with his wife. Master. Brooke
Thou shalt know him for knave and cuckold,
Come to me soon at night.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: What a damned epicurean is this?
My wife hath sent for him, the plot is laid:
Page is an Ass, a fool. A secure Ass,
I will sooner trust an Irishman with my
Aqua-vita bottle, Sir Hu our parson with my cheese,
A thief to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife
With herself: then she plots, then she ruminates,
And what she thinks in her heart she may effect,
She will break her heart but she will effect it.
God be praised, God be praised for my jealousy:
Well I will go prevent him, the time draws on,
Better an hour too soon, than a minute too late,
Gods my life cuckold, cuckold.

div2.stage: Enter the Doctor and his man.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Iohn Rugbie go look met your eyes over the stall,
And spy and you can see the parson.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Sir I cannot tell whether he be there or no,
But I see a great many coming.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Bully moy, mon rapier Iohn Rugabie, begar the
Hearing be not so dead as I shall make him.

div2.stage: Enter Shallow, Page, my Host, and Slender.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: God save you Master.Doctor Cayus.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: How do you Master. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: God bless thee my bully doctor, God bless thee,

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: What be all you, one two three come for, ah?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Bully to see thee fight, to see thee foin, to
see thee traverse, to see thee here, to see thee there,
to see thee pass the punto. The stock, the reverse,
the distance: the montant is he dead my francoyes?
Is he dead my Ethiopian? Ha what says my gallon?
my escuolapis? Is he dead bullies tail, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar the priest be a coward Iack knave,
He dare not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Thou art a castallian king urinal.
Hector of Greece my boy.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: He hath shown himself the wiser man
Master. Doctor:
Sir Hugh is a Parson, and you a Physician. You must
Go with me Master. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Pardon bully Justice. A word monsieur mockwater.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Mockwater, what me that?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That is in our English tongue, Valour bully,
valour.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar then I have as mockuater as the Inglish
Iack dog, knave.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He will clapperclaw thee titely bully.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Clapperclaw, what be that?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar I do look he shall clapperclaw me then,
And I will provoke him to do it, or let him wag:
And moreover bully, but Master. Page and Master.Shallow
And eke cauellira Slender, go you all over the fields
to Frogmore?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He is there: go see what humour he is in,
I will bring the Doctor about by the fields:
Will it do well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: We will do it my host. Farewell Master.Doctor.

div2.stage: Exit all but the Host and Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar I will kill the cowardly Iack priest,
He is make a fool of moy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let him die, but first sheath your impatience,
Throw cold water on your colour, come go with me
Through the fields to Frogmore, and I will bring thee
Where mistress Anne Page is a-feasting at a farm house,
And thou shalt wear her cried game: said I well bully

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar excellent well: and if you speak pour
, I shall procure you the guest of all the gentlemen
mon patients. I begar I shall.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: For the which I will be thy adversary
To mistress Anne Page: Said I well?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Aye begar excellent.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let us wag then.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Alon, alon, alon.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I pray you do so much as see if you can espy
Doctor Cayus coming, and give me intelligence,
Or bring me word if you please now.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Ieshu bless me, how my heart trobes, and trobes,
And then she made him beds of Roses,
And a thousand fragrant poses,
To shallow rivers.
Now so kad vdge me, my heart
Swells more and more. Methinks I can cry
Very well.
There dwelt a man in Babylon,
To shallow rivers and to falls,
Melodious birds sing Madrigalles.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sir here is Master. Page, and Master. Shallow,
Coming hither as fast as they can.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Then it is very necessary I put up my sword,
Pray give me my gown too, mark you.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: God save you Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: God save you Master. parson

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: God bless you all from his mercies sake now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What the word and the sword, doth that agree well?

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: There is reasons and causes in all things,
I warrant you now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Well Sir Hugh, we are come to crave
Your help and furtherance in a matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: What is I pray you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Ifaith it is this sir Hugh. There is an ancient
friend of ours, a man of very good sort, so at odds
with one patience, that I am sure you would heartily
grieve to see him. Now Sir Hugh, you are a scholar
well read, and very persuasive, we would entreat
you to see if you could entreat him to patience.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I pray you who is it? Let us know that.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am sure you know him, it is Doctor Cayus.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I had as lieve you should tell me of a mess of porridge,
He is an arrant lousy beggarly knave:
And he is a coward beside.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why I will lay my life it is the man
That he should fight withal.

div2.stage: Enter Doctor and the Host, they offer to fight.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Keep them asunder, take away their weapons.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Disarm, let them question.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Let them keep their limbs hole, and hack
our English.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Hark one word in your ear. You be vn daga
And the Iack, coward priest.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.p:
Hark you, let us not be laughing stocks
to other men's humours. By Ieshu I will knock your
urinals about your knaues cockscombs, for missing
your meetings and appointments.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: O Ieshu mine host of the garter, Iohn Rogoby,
Have I not met him at the place he make appoint,
Have I not?

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: So kad vdge me, this is the appointment place,
Witness by my Host of the garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Peace I say gawle and gawlia, French and Welsh,
Soul curer, and body curer.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: This is very brave, excellent.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Peace I say, hear mine host of the garter,
Am I wise? am I politic? am I Matchauil?
Shall I lose my doctor? No, he gives me the motions
And the potions. Shall I lose my parson, my sir Hu?
No, he gives me the proverbs, and the noverbs:
Give me thy hand terrestrial,
So give me thy hand celestial:
So boys of art I have deceived you both,
I have directed you to wrong places,
Your hearts are mighty, you skins are whole,
Bardolfe lay their swords to pawn. Follow me lads
Of peace, follow me. Ha, ra, la. Follow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Afore God a mad host, come let us go.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I begar have you mocka me thus?
I will be even met you my Iack Host.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Give me your hand Doctor Cayus,
We be all friends:
But for mine hosts foolish knavery, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I that be well begar I be friends.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: The time draws on he should come to my house,
Well wife, you had best work closely,
Or I am like to go beyond your cunning:
I now will seek my guest that comes to dinner,
And in good time see where they all are come.
By my faith a knot well met: you are welcome all.

div2.stage: Enter Shallow, Page, host, Slender, Doctor,and sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I thank you good Master Ford

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Welcome good Master Page,
I would your daughter were here

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I thank you sir, she is very well at home

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Father Page I hope I have your consent
For Mistress Anne?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You have son Slender, but my wife here,
Is altogether for master Doctor

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Begar I thank her heartily:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But what say you to young Master Fenton?
He capers, he dances, he writes verses, he smells
All April and May: he will carry it, he will carry it,
It is in his betimes he will carry it

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: My host not with my consent: the gentleman is
Wild, he knows too much: If he take her,
Let him take her simply: for my goods goes
With my liking, and my liking goes not that way

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well I pray go home with me to dinner:
Besides your cheer I will show you wonders: I will
Show you a monster You shall go with me
Master Page, and so shall you sir Hugh, and you Master
Doctor

sp.speaker: S Hu.
sp.l: If there be one in the company, I shall make two:

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And there be one-two, I shall make the third:
Sir Hu, In your teeth for shame,

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: well, well, God be with you, we shall have the fairer
Wooing at Master Pages:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I will to my honest knight sir Iohn Falstaffe.
And drink Canary with him.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I may chance to make him drink in pipe wine,
First come gentlemen.

div2.stage: Enter Mistresse Ford, with two of her men, and a great buck busket.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: Sirrah, if your Master. ask you whither
You carry this basket, say to the Launderers,
I hope you know how to bestow it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I warrant you mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis.For.
sp.l: Go get you in. Well sir Iohn,
I believe I shall serve you such a trick,
You shall have little mind to come again.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Have I caught my heavenly Jewel?
Why now let me die. I have lived long enough,
This is the happy hour I have desired to see,
Now shall I sin in my wish,
I would thy husband were dead.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Why how then sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: By the Lord, I would make thee my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Alas sir Iohn, I should be a very simple Lady.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Go to, I see how thy eye doth emulate the Diamond.
And how the arched bent of thy brow
Would become the ship tire, the tire velvet,
Or any Venetian attire, I see it.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: A plain kercher sir Iohn, would fit me better.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: By the Lord thou art a traitor to say so:
What made me love thee? Let that persuade thee
There is somewhat extraordinary in thee: Go to
I love thee:
Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate, like one
Of these fellows that smells like Bucklers-berie,
In simple time, but I love thee,
And none but thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, I am afraid you love mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Aye thou mightst as well say
I love to walk by the Counter gate,
Which is as hateful to me
As the reek of a lime kill.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Mistress Ford, Mistress. Ford, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: O Lord step aside good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: How now Mistress Page what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Why your husband woman is coming,
With half Windsor at his heels,
To look for a gentleman that he says
Is hid in his house: his wifes sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Speak louder. But I hope it is not true Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: It is too true woman. Therefore if you
Have any here, away with him, or you are undone forever.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Alas mistress Page, what shall I do?
Here is a gentleman my friend, how shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.p:
Gode body woman, do not stand what
shall I do, and what shall I do. Better any shift, rather
than you shamed. Look here, here is a buck-basket,
if he be a man of any reasonable size, he will in here.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.p: Alas I fear he is too big.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Let me see, let me see, I will in, I will in,
Follow your friends counsel.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Fie sir Iohn is this your love? Go to.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I love thee, and none but thee:
Help me to convey me hence,
I will never come here more.

div2.stage: Sir Iohn goes into the basket, they put cloathes ouer him, the two men carries it away: Foord meetes it, and all the rest, Page, Doctor, Priest, Slender, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Come pray along, you shall see all.
How now who goes here? whither goes this?
Whither goes it? set it down.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.p:
Now let it go, you had best meddle with
buck-washing.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Buck, good buck, pray come along,
Master Page, take my keys: help to search. Good
Sir Hugh pray come along, help a little, a little,
I will show you all.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: By Ieshu these are jealousies and distempers.

div2.stage: Enter Mistress Page and Mistress Ford

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: He is in a pitiful taking.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: I wonder what he thought
Why my husband bad them set down the basket.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Hang him dishonest slave, we cannot use
Him bad enough. This is excellent for your
Husbands jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mi. For
sp.l: Alas poor soul it grieves me at the heart,
But this will be a means to make him cease
His jealous fits, if Falstaffes love increase.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Nay we will send to Falstaffe once again,
It is great pity we should leave him:
What wives may be merry, and yet honest too.

sp.speaker: Mi. For
sp.l: Shall we be condemned because we laugh?
It is old, but true: still sows eat all the draff.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Here comes your husband, stand aside.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I can find nobody within, it may be he lied.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Did you hear that?

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Aye, aye, peace.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well I will not let it go so, yet I will try further.

sp.speaker: S. Hu.
sp.l: By Ieshu if there be anybody in the kitchen
Or the cupboards, or the press, or the buttery,
I am an arrant Jew: Now God bless me:
You serve me well, do you not?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Fie Master. Ford you are to blame:

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Ifaith it is not well Master. Ford to suspect
Her thus without cause.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: No by my trot it be no well :

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well I pray bear with me, Master.Page pardon me.
I suffer for it, I suffer for it:

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: You suffer for a bad conscience look you now:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well I pray no more, another time I will tell you all:
The mean time go dine with me, pardon me wife,
I am sorry. Master. Page pray go in to dinner,
Another time I will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Well let it be so, and tomorrow I invite you all
To my house to dinner: and in the morning we will
A birding, I have an excellent Hawk for the bush.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Let it be so: Come Master. Page, come wife:
I pray you come in all, you are welcome, pray come in.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: By so kad vdgme, Master. Fordes is
Not in his right wits:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe brew me a pottle sack presently:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: With Eggs sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Simply of itself , I will none of these pullets sperm
In my drink: go make haste.
Have I lived to be carried in a basket
and thrown into the Thames like a barrow of Butchers
offal. Well, if be served such another
trick, I will give them leave to take out my brains
and butter them, and give them to a dog for a new year's gift. 'sblood, the rogues slided me in with as
little remorse as if they had gone to drown a blind
bitches puppies in the litter: and they might know
by my size I have a kind of alacrity in sinking: if
the bottom had been as deep as hell I should down.
I had been drowned, but that the shore was shelvy
and somewhat shallow: a death that I abhor.
For you know the water swells a man: and what a
thing should I have been when I had been swelled?
By the Lord a mountain of money. Now is the
Sack brewed?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Aye sir, there is a woman below would speak
with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Bid her come up. Let me put some Sack
among this cold water, for my belly is as cold as if I
had swallowed snow-balls for pills.
Now what is the news with you?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: I come from mistress Ford forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, I have had Ford enough,
I have been thrown into the Ford, my belly is full Of Ford:
she hath tickled me.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p:
O Lord sir, she is the sorrowfullest woman
that her servants mistook, that ever lived. And sir,
she would desire you of all loves you will meet her
once again, tomorrow sir, between ten and eleven,
and she hopes to make amends for all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ten, and eleven, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Aye forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, tell her I will meet her. Let her but think
Of man's frailty: Let her judge what man is,
And then think of me. And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: You will not fail sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I will not fail. Commend me to her.
I wonder I hear not of Master. Brooke, I like his
Money well. By the mass here he is.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Welcome good Master. Brooke. You come to
know how matters goes.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: That is my coming indeed sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master. Brooke I will not lie to you sir,
I was there at my appointed time.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: And how sped you sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very ill-favouredly sir.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Why sir, did she change her determination?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No Master. Brooke, but you shall hear. After we
had kissed and embraced, and as it were even amid
the prologue of our encounter, who should come,
but the jealous knave her husband, and a rabble of
his companions at his heels, thither provoked and
instigated by his distemper. And what to do think
you? to search for his wife's love. Even so, plainly
so.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: While ye were there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Whilst I was there.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: And did he search and could not find you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You shall hear sir, as God would have it,
A little before comes me one Pages wife,
Gives her intelligence of her husbands
Approach: and by her invention, and Fords wives
Distraction, conveyed me into a buck basket.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: A buck basket!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: By the Lord a buck basket, rammed me in
With foul shirts, stockings, greasy napkins,
That Master. Brooke, there was a compound of the most
Villainous smell, that ever offended nostril.
I will tell you Master. Brooke, by the Lord for your sake
I suffered three egregious deaths: First to be
Crammed like a good bilbo, in the circumference
Of a pack, Hilt to point, heel to head: and then to
Be stewed in my own grease like a Dutch dish:
A man of my kidney; by the Lord it was marvel I
Escaped suffocation; and in the heat of all this,
To be thrown into Thames like a horseshoe hot:
Master Brooke, think of that hissing heat, Master
Brooke.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well sir then my suit is void?
You will undertake it no more?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Master. Brooke, I will be thrown into Etna
As I have been in the Thames,
Ere I thus leave her: I have received
Another appointment of meeting,
Between ten and eleven is the hour.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Why sir, it is almost ten already:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Is it? why then will I address myself
For my appointment: Master. Brooke come to me soon
At night, and you shall know how I speed,
And the end shall be, you shall enjoy her love:
You shall cuckold Foord: Come to me soon at night.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Is this a dream? Is it a vision?
Master Ford, master Ford, awake master Ford,
There is a hole made in your best coat Master. Ford,
And a man shall not only endure this wrong,
But shall stand under the taunt of names,
Lucifer is a good name, Barbason good : good
Devils names: But cuckold, wittold, godeso
The devil himself hath not such a name:
And they may hang hats here, and napkins here
Upon my horns: Well I will home, I ferret him,
And unless the devil himself should aid him,
I will search unpossible places: I will about it,
Least I repent too late:

div2.stage: Enter M. Fenton, Page, and mistresse Quickly.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Tell me sweet Nan, how doest thou yet resolve,
Shall foolish Slender have thee to his wife?
Or one as wise as he, the learned Doctor?
Shall such as they enjoy thy maiden heart?
Thou knowest that I have always loved thee dear,
And thou hast oft times swore the like to me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Good Master. Fenton, you may assure yourself
My heart is settled upon none but you,
It is as my father and mother please:
Get their consent, you quickly shall have mine.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Thy father thinks I love thee for his wealth,
ThoughI must needs confess at first that drew me,
But since thy virtues wiped that trash away,
I love thee Nan, and so dear is it set,
That whilst I live, I never shall thee forget.
Godes pity here comes her father.

div2.stage: Enter M. Page his wife, M. Shallow, and Slender.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Master. Fenton I pray what make you here?
You know my answer sir, she is not for you:
Knowing my vow, to blame to use me thus.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: But hear me speak sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Pray sir get you gon: Come hither daughter,
Son Slender let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Speak to Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Pray mistress Page let me have your consent.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Ifaith Master. Fenton it is as my husband please.
For my part I will neither hinder you, nor further you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: How say you this was my doings?
I bid you speak to mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Here nurse, there is a brace of angels to drink,
Work what thou canst for me, farewell.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: By my troth so I will, good heart.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Come wife, you and I will in, we will leave Master.
And my daughter to talk together. Master. Shallow,
You may stay sir if you please.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Marry I thank you for that:
To her cousin, to her.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Ifaith I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now Master. Slender, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Godeso there is a Jest indeed: why mistress Anne,
I never made will yet: I thank God I am wise enough for that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Fie cuss fie, thou art not right,
O thou hadst a father.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I had a father mistress Anne, good uncle
Tell the Jest how my father stole the goose out of
The henloft. All this is nought, hark you mistress
Anne.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: He will make you jointure of three hundred pound a year, he shall make you a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.l: Aye begod that I will, come cut and long tail, as good as any is in Glostershire, under the degree of a Squire.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: O God how many gross faults are hid,
And covered in three hundred pound a year?
Well Master. Slender, within a day or two I will tell you
more.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.l: I thank you good mistress Anne, uncle I shall have her.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p:
Master. Shallow, Master. Page would pray you to
come you, and you Master. Slender, and you mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: Slend.
sp.l: Well Nurse, if you will speak for me,
I will give you more than I will talk of.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Indeed I will, I will speak what I can for you,
But specially for Master. Fenton:
But specially of all for my Master.
And indeed I will do what I can for them all three.

div2.stage: Enter misteris Ford and her two men.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.p:
Do you hear? when your Master. comes
take up this basket as you did before, and if your Master.
bid you set it down, obey hiM.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Sir Iohn welcome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What are you sure of your husband now?

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: He is gone a-birding sir Iohn, and I hope
will not come home yet.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Gods body here is mistress Page,
Step behind the arras good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, why woman your husband
is in his old vain again, he is coming to search
for your sweetheart, but I am glad he is not here.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.p:
O God mistress Page the knight is here,
What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.p:
Why then you are undone woman, unless
you make some means to shift him away.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.p:
Alas I know no means, unless
we put him in the basket again.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No I will come no more in the basket,
I will creep up into the chimney.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: There they use to discharge their Following pieces.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why then I will go out of doors.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.l: Then you are undone, you are but a dead man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: For Gods sake devise any extremity,
Rather than a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Alas I know not what means to make,
If there were any woman's apparel would fit him,
He might put on a gown and a muffler,
And so escape.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: That is well remembered, my maids Aunt
Gillian of Brainford, hath a gown above.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: And she is altogether as fat as he.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Aye that will serve him of my word.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Come go with me sir Iohn, I will help to dress you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come for God sake, anything .

div2.stage: Exit Mis. Page, and Sir Iohn. Enter M. Ford, Page, Priest, Shallow, the two men carries the basket, and Ford meets it.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Come along I pray, you shall know the cause,
How now whither go you? Ha whither go you?
Set down the basket you slave,
You panderly rogue set it down.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: What is the reason that you use me thus

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Come hither set down the basket,
Mistress Ford the modest woman,
Mistress Ford the virtuous woman,
She that hath the jealous fool to her husband,
I mistrust you without cause do I not?

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: Aye Gods my record do you. And if
you mistrust me in any ill sort.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well said brazen face, hold it out,
You youth in a basket, come out here,
Pull out the clothes, search.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Ieshu bless me, will you pull up your wife's clothes?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Fie Master. Ford you are not to go abroad if you be in these fits.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: By so kad vdge me, it is very necessary
He were put in pethleM.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Master. Page, as I am an honest man Master. Page,
There was one conveyed out of my house here yesterday
out of this basket, why may he not be here
now?

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Come mistress Page, bring the old woman down.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Old woman, what old woman?

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Why my maidens Ant, Gillean of Brainford.
A witch, have I not forewarned her my house,
Alas we are simple we, we know not what
Is brought to pass under the colour of fortune Telling.
Come down you witch, come down.

div2.stage: Enter Falstaffe disguised like an old woman, and misteris Page with him, Ford beates him, and hee runnes away.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Away you witch get you gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: By Ieshu I verily think she is a witch indeed,
I espied under her muffler a great beard.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Pray come help me to search, pray now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Come we will go for his minds sake.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.p: By my troth he beat him most extremely.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.p:
I am glad of it, what shall we proceed any
further?

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.p:
No faith, now if you will let us tell our
husbands of it. For mine I am sure hath almost fretted
himself to death.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.p:
Content, come we will go tell them all,
And as they agree, so will we proceed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Sir here be three Gentlemen come from
the Duke the Stanger sir, would have your horse.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The Duke, what Duke? let me speak with
the Gentlemen, do they speak English?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I will call them to you sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: No Bardolfe, let them alone, I will sauce them:
They have had my house a week at command,
I have turned away my other guess,
They shall have my horses Bardolfe,
They must come off, I will sauce them.

div2.stage: Enter Ford, Page, their wiues, Shallow, and Slender. Syr Hu.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Well wife, here take my hand, upon my
soul I love thee dearer than I do my life, and joy I
have so true and constant wife, my jealousy shall
never more offend thee.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Sir I am glad, and that which I have done,
Was nothing else but mirth and modesty.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Aye mistress Ford, Falstaffe hath all the grief,
And in this knavery my wife was the chief.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.l: No knavery husband, it was honest mirth.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Indeed it was good pastimes and merriments.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: But sweetheart shall we leave old
Falstaffe so?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: O by no means, send to him again.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do not think he will come being so much
deceived.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Let me alone, I will to him once again like
Brooke, and know his mind whether he will come
or not.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: There must be some plot laid, or he will not come.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Let us alone for that. Hear my device.
Oft have you heard since Horne the hunter dyed,
That women to affright their little children,
Says that he walks in shape of a great stag.
Now for that Falstaffe hath been so deceived,
As that he dares not venture to the house,
We will send him word to meet us in the field,
Disguised like Horne, with huge horns on his head,
The hour shall be just between twelve and one,
And at that time we will meet him both:
Then would I have you present there at hand,
With little boys disguised and dressed like Fairies,
For to affright fat Falstaffe in the woods.
And then to make a period to the Jest,
Tell Falstaffe all, I think this will do best.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It is excellent, and my daughter Anne,
Shall like a little Fairy be disguised.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.p:
And in that Mask I will make the Doctor
steal my daughter Anne, and ere my husband knows
it, to carry her to Church, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Mis. For.
sp.l: But who will buy the silks to tire the boys?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: That will I do, and in a robe of white
I will clothe my daughter, and advertise Slender
To know her by that sign, and steal her thence,
And unknown to my wife, shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: So kad vdge me the devices is excellent.
I will also be there, and be like a Iackanapes,
And pinch him most cruelly for his lecheries.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Why then we are revenged sufficiently.
First he was carried and thrown in the Thames,
Next beaten well, I am sure you will witness that.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: I will lay my life this makes him nothing fat.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Well let us about this stratagem, I long
To see deceit deceived, and wrong have wrong.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well send to Falstaffe, and if he come thither,
It will make us smile and laugh one month together.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What would thou have boar, what thick skin?
Speak, breath, discus, short, quick, brief, snap.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sir, I am sent from my Master. to sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, there is his Castle, his standing bed,
his trundle bed, his chamber is painted about with
the story of the prodigal, fresh and new, go knock,
he will speak like an Antripophiginian to thee:
Knock I say.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Sir I should speak with an old woman that
went up into his chamber.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: An old woman, the knight may be robbed,
I will call bully knight, bully sir Iohn. Speak from thy
Lungs military: it is thine host, thy Ephesian calls.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now mine Host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here is a Bohemian tarter bully, tarries the
coming down of the fat woman: Let her descend
bully, let her descend, my chambers are honourable,
pah privacy, fie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Indeed mine host there was a fat woman with me,
But she is gone.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pray sir was it not the wise woman of Brainford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Marry was it Musselshell, what would you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Marry sir my master Slender sent me to her,
To know whether one Nim that hath his chain,
Cozened him of it, or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I talked with the woman about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And I pray sir what says she?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Marry she says the very same man that
Beguiled master Slender of his chain,
Cozened him of it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: May I be bold to tell my master so sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Aye tike, who more bold.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
I thank you sir, I shall make my master a
glad man at these tidings, God be with you sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Thou art clerkly sir Iohn, thou art clerkly,
Was there a wise woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Marry was there mine host, one that taught
Me more wit than I learned this 7. year,
And I paid nothing for it,
But was paid for my learning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O Lord sir cozenage, plain cozenage.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why man, where be my horses? where be
the Germanes?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Rid away with your horses:
After I came beyond Maidenhead,
They flung me in a slough of mire, and away they ran.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Where be my Host the garter?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O here sir in perplexity.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I cannot tell what be that,
But begar I will tell you one thing,
There be a German Duke come to the Court,
Has cozened all the host of Branford,
And Redding: begar I tell you for good will,
Ha, ha, mine Host, am I even met you?

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Where is mine Host of the garter?
Now my Host, I would desire you look you now,
To have a care of your entertainments,
For there is three sorts of cousin-garmombles,
Is cousin all the Host of Maidenhead and Readings,
Now you are an honest man, and a scurvy beggarly lousy knave beside:
And can point wrong places,
I tell you for good will, grate why mine Host

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I am cozened Hugh, and coy Bardolfe,
Sweet knight assist me, I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Would all the world were cozened for me,
For I am cozened and beaten too.
Well, I never prospered since I forswore
Myself at Primero: if my wind
Were but long enough to say my prayers,
I would repent, now from whence come you?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: From the two parties forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: The devil take the one party,
And his dam the other,
And they will be both bestowed.
I have endured more for their sakes,
Than man is able to endure.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: O Lord sir, they are the sorrowfullest creatures
That ever lived: specially mistress Ford,
Her husband hath beaten her that she is all
Black and blue poor soul.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What tellest me of black and blue,
I have been beaten all the colours in the Rainbow,
And in my escape like to have been apprehended
For a witch of Brainford, and set in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Well sir, she is a sorrowful woman,
And I hope when you hear my errant,
You will be persuaded to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come go with me into my chamber, I will hear thee.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Speak not to me sir, my mind is heavy,
I have had a great loss.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Yet hear me, and as I am a gentleman,
I will give you a hundred pound toward your loss.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well sir I will hear you, and at least keep your counsel.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Then thus my host. It is not unknown to you,
The fervent love I bear to young Anne Page,
And mutely her love again to me:
But her father still against her choice,
Doth seek to marry her to foolish Slender,
And in a robe of white this night disguised,
Wherein fat Falstaffe had a mighty scare,
Must Slender take her and carry her to Catlen,
And there unknown to any, marry her.
Now her mother still against that match,
And firm for Doctor Cayus, in a robe of red
By her device, the Doctor must steal her thence,
And she hath given consent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now which means she to deceive, father or mother?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Both my good Host, to go along with me.
Now here it rests, that you would procure a priest,
And tarry ready at the appointment place,
To give our hearts united matrimony.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But how will you come to steal her from among them

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: That hath sweet Nan and I agreed upon,
And by a robe of white, the which she wears,
With ribbons pendant flaring about her head,
I shall be sure to know her, and convey her thence,
And bring her where the priest abides our coming,
And by thy furtherance there be married.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well, husband your device, I will to the Vicar,
Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a Priest.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: So shall I evermore be bound unto thee.
Besides I will always be thy faithful friend.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn with a Bucks head vpon him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This is the third time, well I will venture,
They say there is good luck in old numbers,
Jove transformed himself into a bull,
And I am here a Stag, and I think the fattest
In all Windsor forest: well I stand here
For Horne the hunter, waiting my Doe's coming.

div2.stage: Enter mistris Page, and mistris Ford.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, where are you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Art thou come my doe? what and thou too?
Welcome Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Aye aye sir Iohn, I see you will not fail,
Therefore you deserve far better than our loves,
But it grieves me for your late crosses.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This makes amends for all.
Come divide me between you, each a haunch,
For my horns I will bequeath them to your husbands,
Do I speak like Horne the hunter, ha?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: God forgive me, what noise is this?

div2.stage: There is a noise of hornes, the two women run away. Enter sir Hugh like a Satyre, and boyes drest like Fayries, mistresse Quickly, like the Queene of Fayries: they sing a song about him, and afterward speake.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: You Fairies that do haunt these shady groves,
Look round about the wood if you can espy
A mortal that doth haunt our sacred round:
If such a one you can espy, give him his due,
And leave not till you pinch him black and blue:
Give them their charge Puck ere they part away.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Come hither Peane, go to the country houses,
And when you find a slut that lies asleep,
And all her dishes foul, and room unswepted,
With your long nails pinch her till she cry,
And swear to mend her sluttish housewifery.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: I warrant you I will perform your will.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Where is Pead? go you and see where Brokers sleep,
And Fox-eyed Sergeants with their mace,
Go lay the Proctors in the street,
And pinch the lousy Sergeant's face:
Spare none of these when they are abed,
But such whose nose looks blue and red.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Away begone, his mind fulfil,
And look that none of you stand still.
Some do that thing, some do this,
All do something, none amiss.

sp.speaker: Hir Hu.
sp.l: I smell a man of middle earth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: God bless me from that welsh Fairy.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Look every one about this round,
And if that any here be found,
For his presumption in this place,
Spare neither leg, arm, head, nor face.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: See I have spied one by good luck,
His body man, his head a buck.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: God send me good fortune now, and I care not.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Go strait, and do as I command,
And take a Taper in your hand,
And set it to his fingers ends,
And if you see it him offends,
And that he starteth at the flame,
Then is he mortal, know his name:
If with an F. it doth begin,
Why then be sure he is full of sin.
About it then, and know the truth,
Of this same metamorphosed youth.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Give me the Tapers, I will try
And if that he love venery.

div2.stage: They put the Tapers to his fingers, and he starts.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: It is right indeed, he is full of lecheries and iniquity.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: A little distant from him stand,
And every one take hand in hand,
And compass him within a ring,
First pinch him well, and after sing.

div2.stage: Here they pinch him, and sing about him, and the Doctor comes one way and steales away a boy in red. And Slender another way he takes a boy in greene: And Fenton steales misteris Anne, being in white. And a noyse of hunting is made within: and all the Fairies runne away. Falstaffe pulles of his bucks head, and rises vp. And enters M. Page, M. Ford, and their wiues, M. Shallow, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Horne the hunter quoth you: am I a ghost?
'sblood the Fairies hath made a ghost of me:
What hunting at this time at night?
I will lay my life the mad Prince of Wales
Is stealing his fathers Deer.
How now who have
we here, what is all Windsor stirring? Are you there?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: God save you sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why how now sir Iohn, what a pair of horns in your hand?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Those horns he meant to place upon my head,
And Master. Brooke and he should be the men:
Why how now sir Iohn, why are you thus amazed?
We know the Fairies man that pinched you so,
Your throwing in the Thames, your beating well,
And what is to come sir Iohn, that can we tell.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.l: Sir Iohn it is thus, your dishonest means
To call our credits into question,
Did make us undertake to our best,
To turn your lewd lust to a merry Jest.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Jest, it is well, have I lived to these years
To be gulled now, now to be ridden?
Why then these were not Fairies?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: No sir Iohn but boys.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: By the Lord I was twice or thrice in the mind
They were not, and yet the grossness
Of the foppery persuaded me they were.
Well, and the fine wits of the Court hear this,
They will so whip me with their keen Jests,
That they will melt me out like tallow,
Drop by drop out of my grease. Boys!

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I trust me boys Sir Iohn: and I was
Also a Fairy that did help to pinch you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I, it is well I am your May-pole,
You have the start of me,
Am I ridden too with a welsh goat?
With a piece of toasted cheese?

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Butter is better than cheese sir Iohn,
You are all butter, butter.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: There is a further matter yet sir Iohn,
There is 20. pound you borrowed of Master. Brooke Sir Iohn,
And it must be paid to Master. Ford Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Nay husband let that go to make amends,
Forgive that sum, and so we will all be friends.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well here is my hand, all is forgiven at last.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It hath cost me well,
I have been well pinched and washed.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pa.
sp.l: Master. Doctor, son I hope you are.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Son begar you be the vile woman,
Begar I think to marry mistress Anne, and begar
It is a whoreson garcon Iack boy.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: How a boy?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Aye begar a boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Nay be not angry wife, I will tell thee true,
It was my plot to deceive thee so:
And by this time your daughter is married
To Master. Slender, and see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Now son Slender,
Where is your bride?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Bride, by Gods lyd I think there is never a
man in the world hath that cross fortune that I
have: begod I could cry for very anger.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why what is the matter son Slender?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Son, nay by God I am none of your son.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, why so?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Why so God save me, it is a boy that I have married.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: How a boy? why did you mistake the word?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
No neither, for I came to her in red as you
bad me, and I cried mum, and he cried budget, so
well as ever you heard, and I have married him.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Ieshu Master. Slender, cannot you see but marry boys?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O I am vexed at heart, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Here comes the man that hath deceived us all:
How now daughter, where have you been?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: At Church forsooth.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: At Church, what have you done there?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Married to me, nay sir never storm,
It is done sir now, and cannot be undone.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I faith Master. Page never chafe yourself,
She hath made her choice whereas her heart was fixed,
Then it is in vain for you to storm or fret.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am glad yet that your arrow hath glanced

sp.speaker: Mi. For.
sp.l: Come mistress Page, I will be bold with you,
It is pity to part love that is so true.

sp.speaker: Mis. Pa.
sp.l: Although that I have missed in my intent,
Yet I am glad my husband's match was crossed,
Here Master. Fenton, take her, and God give thee joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: Come Master. Page, you must needs agree.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: I yfaith sir come, you see your wife is well pleased:

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I cannot tell, and yet my heart is well eased,
And yet it doth me good the Doctor missed.
Come hither Fenton, and come hither daughter,
Go to you might have stayed for my good will,
But since your choice is made of one you love,
Here take her Fenton, and both happy prove.

sp.speaker: Sir Hu.
sp.l: I will also dance and eat plums at your weddings.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: All parties pleased, now let us in to feast,
And laugh at Slender, and the Doctors jest.
He hath got the maiden, each of you a boy
To wait upon you, so God give you joy,
And sir Iohn Falstaffe now shall you keep your word,
For Brooke this night shall lie with mistress Ford.
